Mukasey to questions submitted for the record by the Honorable Brad Sherman, a Representative in Congress from the State of California..................................................... 92 </option> <Doc-title>AUTHORIZATION FOR THE USE OF MILITARY FORCE AND CURRENT TERRORIST THREATS</Doc-title> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="">Washington, DC.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker=""> The committee met, pursuant to notice, at 10:00 a.m., in room 2172 Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Edward Royce (chairman of the committee) presiding. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Royce">This hearing will come to order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">Today we are going to review a critical national security issue: The role of Congress in authorizing the use of military force. We have a very distinguished panel to help us do so.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce">Our Nation continues to face the threat of radical jihadist terrorism. We have confronted this deadly movement with some measure of success, largely because of the skill, the dedication, and the sacrifice of the brave men and women of our armed services. But as recent attacks on the United States and our allies--such as the United Kingdom--show, the threat remains high. Our response must be coordinated, using information and economic tools, too.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">Today, most U.S. combat operations are conducted under the Authorization for the Use of Military Force, or the AUMF, that was enacted following the vicious September 11th, 2001 attacks on our country. That AUMF has been used against al-Qaeda, the Taliban, and what have since become known as ``associated forces.'' Nearly 3 years ago, the Obama administration determined that those forces include ISIS, which originated as al-Qaeda in Iraq.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Royce">The continued reliance on this legal authority has spurred debate. Some maintain that the 2001 AUMF has been stretched too far. Some believe that Congress--most of whose members were not here in 2001--should debate and reauthorize our military engagement. We have Members of Congress who have fought these wars, whose voices carry strong weight.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Royce">Over the last several years, this committee has conducted more than 45 hearings related to conflicts fought under the AUMF and we have often met in classified settings with military commanders and other officials to review the grave terrorist threat against our Nation. I know that our members on both sides of the aisle take their responsibilities very seriously. We have had many conversations about the AUMF.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Royce">I believe that the President has the authority under the 2001 AUMF to defeat and destroy ISIS. Key outside experts and officials from the previous administration who have appeared before this committee have testified to this. But I also believe that a new and updated authorization for the use of military force would be ideal. The challenge is getting agreement on what exactly it should contain.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Royce">Proposed replacements vary widely. Some would empower the Commander in Chief. Others would constrain him. Some would target groups. Others would target ideologies. Some are limited in time and place and type of military force. Others are unlimited.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Royce">What I cannot support is any effort to repeal the 2001 AUMF before reaching consensus on these issues. We face determined enemies--al-Qaeda, ISIS, and the Taliban--absolutely committed to harming us. There shouldn't be any signs of wavering in our fight.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Royce">Today's witnesses will shed light on a few key questions: Does the 2001 AUMF provide sufficient legal authority to deal with all of today's threats? Does continuing to rely on that authorization create any operational challenges or legal dangers? What should--or shouldn't--be a replacement and what should be included in that AUMF?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Royce">Authorizing the use of military force is a critical and solemn congressional responsibility. This committee will continue its focus on it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Royce"> I will now turn to Ranking Member Engel for his statement. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Engel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thank you. Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you for calling this hearing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Engel">To our witnesses, welcome to the Foreign Affairs Committee. We are grateful for your time and expertise.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Engel">The role of Congress in authorizing and overseeing the use of American military force around the world is really such an important issue.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Engel">Some of us have been trying to advance this debate for the last several years. But for the most part, the topic has remained on the back burner in the halls of Congress.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Engel">I am glad we are focusing on it today because I think the need for congressional leadership is more important now than ever.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Engel">The authorization for the use of military force passed by Congress in 2001, and I was here then, authorized the President to take military action against, and I quote, ``those nations, organizations, or persons he determines planned, authorized, committed, or aided the terrorist attacks that occurred on September 11th, 2001, or harbored such organizations or persons.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Engel">In the intervening years, it has been used as a legal justification for military force in a host of countries around the world. Today, it is the legal basis for the fight against</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Engel">That gives you a sense of just how broadly this authorization has been interpreted by successive administrations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Engel">I was here when we passed this measure nearly 16 years ago, and I have to say that none of us envisioned we would still be relying on it nearly two decades later to fight an enemy that didn't even exist when the Twin Towers came down. It has essentially become a blank check.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Engel">Now, whatever you think of President Obama's foreign policy, his administration did come to Congress and ask for an updated authorization.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Engel">The current administration has not, and what concerns me now is that we have seen escalating military activity on a number of fronts--ratcheting up the use of force in Afghanistan, a pledge by the administration to ramp up the fight against ISIS, reckless talk about expanding the Guantanamo Bay Detention Facility--which even President Bush wanted to close--declaring parts of Somalia so-called ``areas of active hostilities,'' which decreased oversight of air strikes and increases the risk that American forces could be drawn into clan conflicts, and strikes against the Assad regime and associated forces.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Engel">Now, I am not saying that we shouldn't do some of this. I am not saying that we should withdraw from these challenges.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Engel">The fight against ISIS is critical to protect the national security of the United States and our allies. We have seen too many murdered children and families and must continue to ensure that Assad does not use chemical weapons and we have invested too much blood and treasure in Afghanistan to stand by and watch it fall back into the hands of extremists.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Engel">But we have to ask ourselves: Are we comfortable sending American service members into harm's way based on a virtually limitless 2001 authorization? If so, what will be the next skirmish supposedly covered by this 16-year-old measure? Extended hostilities toward Assad's forces? Shooting down a Russian MiG? This, to me feels like a slippery slope.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Engel">So Congress needs to do its job. We need to do what we should have <greek-l>d1 deg. done years ago and pass a new authorization governing the conflicts we are engaged in today. And frankly, even though we call it an authorization, what we need is a limitation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Engel">The 2001 authorization is too broad. It needs to be put out to pasture and scaled back. We need an authorization tailored to the challenges we face today, one that gives the administration the tools it needs to ensure our security without dragging us into another war, turning the slippery slope into a dangerous cliff.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Engel">Congress has the power to do this and we need to act. But for us to craft a measure with the right boundaries we need to know what strategies the United States is pursuing in these global hot spots.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Engel">We have U.S. troops on the ground in Syria but we still don't have a clear sense of the end game there or when the troops will come home.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Engel">With the conflict in Afghanistan once again heating up and a disturbing spike in civilian casualties, we have yet to learn the Trump administration's approach to America's longest war.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Engel">And now that we have received the administration's plan to deal with ISIS, I am not clear how it differs at all from the approach of the last administration.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Engel">We haven't heard anything from the administration about how it intends to win the peace in all these places once the fighting is over.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Engel">I can tell you one thing--slashing funding for diplomacy and development is the wrong approach that the administration is doing. Planning a war without planning to secure the peace is a sure path toward future conflict and instability and if we don't have a strong State Department and USAID, we are taking away the tools to build that long-term solution.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Engel">You cannot make foreign policy flying by the seat of your pants, especially when it comes to our men and women in uniform. The administration should be up here explaining how they plan to deal with these conflicts, not careening from crisis to crisis.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Engel">But one way or another, we, Congress, need to act. It is time to retire the 2001 AUMF and stop shirking our responsibility. I have an approach that I have been working on. Other members have offered their views as well.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Engel">If these approaches aren't perfect at first, it doesn't mean we can throw up our hands and walk away. It means we need to work across the aisle to find the right answer and the right approach.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Engel">So I look forward to hearing from our witnesses. I thank you again, Mr. Chairman. I want to hear from our witnesses about the right way to grapple with this problem.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Engel">Before I yield back, I would like to ask unanimous consent that Representative Barbara Lee be allowed to ask questions after all members of the committee have had their chance at this morning's hearing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Engel"> There is strong interest in this issue from the advocacy community. We have received statements for the record from Human Rights First, Third Way, and the Constitution Project as well as a letter from a coalition of human rights, civil liberties, and faith-based organizations and I would also like to ask unanimous consent to enter these documents into the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Chairman Royce">Without objection.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Chairman Royce">We are pleased to welcome our colleague, Congresswoman Barbara Lee from California.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Chairman Royce">And as to your suggested approach there, Mr. Engel, I quite concur. I think it needs to be bipartisan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Chairman Royce">This morning we are pleased to be joined by a distinguished panel that we think will shed light on this.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Chairman Royce">The Honorable Michael Mukasey served as the 81st Attorney General of the United States and as a U.S. district judge in the Southern District of New York.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Chairman Royce">We have Brigadier General Richard Gross, partner at the FH&H law firm in northern Virginia. Previously General Gross served for over 30 years in the U.S. Army. He was the legal counsel to the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Chairman Royce">We have Mr. Matt Olsen, a lecturer on law at Harvard Law School. Previously, Mr. Olsen served as the director of the National Counterterrorism Center.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Chairman Royce">So without objection, the witnesses' full prepared statements will be made part of the record and all members will have 5 calendar days to submit any statements or questions or any extraneous material for the record.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>STATEMENT OF THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEYGENERAL OF THE UNITED STATES)</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">Judge, would you like to begin? Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">GENERAL OF THE UNITED STATES)</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">Judge Mukasey. Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">Before I make any remarks, I'd like to thank both the chair and the ranking member for having invited me and for holding this hearing, which is, as you both pointed out, enormously important and represents a real political commitment to putting this Congress on record as it should be with this country and I really appreciate that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">I am not going to read my statement. It is in the record. I would simply make two additional points that are additional to what I said in my prepared remarks, one having to do with the sunset provision, which I endorsed simply because it does provide for this added opportunity on every several years to recommit to a course of action.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">Obviously, there are authorities that have to remain in force notwithstanding the arrival of a sunset so that, for example, people detained in an initial encounter, notwithstanding the sunset there would have to a be a separate determination with respect to them. It doesn't become a home free all for them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">And secondly, with respect to a requirement or statement of strategy, which I did not touch on in my remarks but I think that, obviously, it is important to have a general idea of what you are going to do. But a statement of strategy that tells your adversaries what it is you plan to do and how it is you plan to do it I don't think is well taken and, as I believe the ranking member pointed out, micro managing any combat is a dangerous thing. So that that ought to be taken into account.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">So far as our not having been able to envision being in Afghanistan 16 years on from 9/11, I should point out that when the bombers hit Pearl Harbor, they did not also drop leaflets that said, don't worry, folks, this is all going to be over by 1945.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="THE HONORABLE MICHAEL B. MUKASEY (FORMER ATTORNEY">You never know when at the beginning of combat how it is going to end. That is the nature of a conflict like this. But I don't think that the fact that we don't precisely know how and when should prevent us from opposing to the extent we can what we are up against.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF BRIGADIER GENERAL RICHARD C. GROSS, USA, RETIRED,</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="BRIGADIER GENERAL RICHARD C. GROSS">General. PARTNER, FLUET HUBER + HOANG, PLLC (FORMER LEGAL COUNSEL TO THE</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="BRIGADIER GENERAL RICHARD C. GROSS">CHAIRMAN OF THE JOINT CHIEFS OF STAFF)</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="BRIGADIER GENERAL RICHARD C. GROSS"> General Gross. Thank you, Chairman Royce. Thank you, Ranking Member Engel and members of the committee. I am very grateful for the opportunity to---- </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">Make sure, General, that you've got that red button on. There we go.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce"> General Gross. It was. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">And maybe pull it a little closer would be the other suggestion.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Royce">General Gross. Yes, sir.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Royce">Again, it is a privilege to appear before the committee today. I am purposely going to keep my remarks brief.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Royce">What I hope to offer the committee is a military, legal practitioner's view of AUMFs and in particular the 2001.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Royce">As you mentioned, I retired after over 30 years in the U.S. Army, both as an infantry officer and as a judge advocate. I was the legal advisor to multiple joint and special operations task forces with multiple deployments to Afghanistan and Iraq.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Royce">I was also the legal advisor for the Joint Special Operations Command, NATO ISAF, U.S. Forces Afghanistan and U.S. Central Command, and in my final 4 years I was General Dempsey's legal advisor on the Joint Staff when he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Royce">I worked closely when I was on the Joint Staff with the DoD general counsel, the National Security Council legal staff, and the interagency lawyers groups on national security law issues to include counterterrorism operations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Royce">I dealt with the 2001 and 2002 AUMFs multiple countless times over those 4 years both in the context of specific targeting operations as well as more general discussions on the scope of the AUMF and proposals to revise or amend it. Many of those discussions actually took place here in Congress in both the Senate and the House in briefings, hearings, and informal discussions with members and congressional staff.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Royce">My views on the 2001 AUMF have not changed since I retired from the military. I continue to feel the 2001 AUMF is adequate. It contains adequate legal authority for the use of military force against the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, which was a view first adopted by the previous administration and I believe to be the position of the current administration.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Royce">I recognize, however, that reasonable minds disagree on this point and many have voiced criticisms of the decision to rely on the 2001 AUMF as the domestic legal authority to conduct military operations against ISIS.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Royce">While I believe the 2001 AUMF is adequate to address the ISIS threat, I also believe it would be prudent for Congress to enact the new AUMF to specifically address the threat of ISIS and other terrorist groups for a variety of reasons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Royce">First, a new AUMF would reflect the current will of the American people as exercised through their elected leaders regarding our ongoing operations against ISIS, al-Qaeda, the Taliban, and other terrorist groups.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Royce">A new AUMF would also define the current scope and extent of our military's mission against terrorist organizations, and finally, a new AUMF would signal congressional support to the U.S. armed forces.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Royce">As the committee considers what provisions a new AUMF might contain, please allow me to give you my perspective as a practitioner.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Royce">When I review an AUMF proposal, I think of it in terms of the mission--who, what, when, where, and how. Against whom are we using force, what force is authorized, and for how long? Where is the use of force authorized? Finally, how are we authorized to use that force? Are there restraints or restrictions?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Royce">To be clear, I do not think it is helpful nor desirable to have all of these elements in an AUMF, a point I will expound upon more in a moment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman Royce">With these elements, there is necessarily a trade-off between transparency and certainty, on one hand, and flexibility for commanders on the other.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman Royce">The more descriptive or proscriptive a provision of AUMF is, the less flexibility it may afford the President and military commanders to pursue a dynamic ever-changing enemy terrorist group.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Chairman Royce">I would urge the committee to carefully consider that balance as it takes up the AUMF proposals.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Chairman Royce">The most critical provision of an AUMF is the who-- identifying the enemy against whom force may be used. Our current enemies do not wear a uniform, hide among civilian populations, and operate in a dynamic, disperse network of clandestine cells. This makes defining them challenging.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Chairman Royce">Given that, there should be some flexibility in the AUMF to account for an ever-changing and expansive nature of the enemy while also defining with affiliates and co-belligerents rise to the level of associated forces.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Chairman Royce">The what element defines the scope of the authorized force. The 2001 AUMF authorized the President to use all necessary and appropriate force. This same language is also used in the Senate Joint Resolution introduced by Senators Flake and Kaine.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Chairman Royce">This particular language provides maximum flexibility to commanders. Other elements--when, where, and how--often appear in AUMF proposals, but these elements may create unintended consequences. I will discuss each of these in turn.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Chairman Royce">The when or for how long element usually arises in the form of a sunset provision which results in the automatic termination of the AUMF after a set period of time. These are generally included as a forcing function, a means of ensuring periodic review of the authority granted by Congress.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Chairman Royce">However, sunset provisions may also create legal uncertainty for the President and military, particularly as the expiration date approaches without action to extend or reauthorize the AUMF.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Chairman Royce">Sunset provisions could also be interpreted by both adversaries and coalition partners as a lack of resolve and could potentially embolden adversaries to wait this out.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Chairman Royce">The where element is typically reflected as a geographic limitation.
